fields.label_text: SUGAR BASIN and COVER. Silver gilt, chased with foliage and rococo knob of shells and scroll-work. French. About 1770. H. 5½ in., diam. 4½ in. Bought, 11 l. 4246-'56.

fields.descriptive_line:
Silver-gilt, France (Paris), 1732-3, mark of Jean-Baptiste de Lens.
[Bowl] Silver-gilt. The bowl has a fluted body, with four applied swags of leaf and floral ornament; the circular foot is decorated with an applied band of fasces.
fields.physical_description:
Silver-gilt bowl with lid, decorated with cast and applied festoons of flowers and rocaille ornament, the lid finial cast as four cockleshells which support a rosette.
[Lid] Silver-gilt. The lid is domed and fluted, with applied swags of leaf and floral ornament. The rim of the lid is decorated with an applied band of fascia. The finial is formed by four rocaille scroll motifs which surround a knop designed as four addorsed shells topped by an artichoke.
fields.dimensions:
Height: 14 cm Base of bowl to top of finial on lid, Diameter: 11 cm Across the mouth of the bowl, Diameter: 6.5 cm Across foot of the bowl, Weight: 592.6 g Bowl and lid together
[Bowl] Weight: 398 g
[Lid] Weight: 194.5 g
fields.materials_techniques: [Lid] Silver-gilt, raised, and with cast, applied decoration.
fields.label: SUGAR BASIN and COVER. Silver gilt, chased with foliage and rococo knob of shells and scroll-work. French. About 1770. H. 5½ in., diam. 4½ in. Bought, 11 l. 4246-'56. [1856]
fields.marks: [Bowl] Maker's mark, initials 'IL' over 'D' with a head between the 'I' and the 'L', and a crowned fleur-de-lis bewteen two grains de remède above, the mark of Jean-Baptiste de Lens. Stamped on rim and base of bowl. Warden's mark, a crowned letter 'Q', for the period 17 September 1732 - 24 September 1733. Stamped on base of bowl. Charge mark, a crowned letter 'A', in use for the period 22 December 1732 to 4 October 1738. Stamped on the base of the bowl. Discharge mark, a dog's head, current for the period 22 December 1732 to 4 October 1738. Stamped on the rim of the bowl foot. Scratch weights on the underside of the bowl. [Lid] Maker's mark, initials 'IL' over 'D' with a head between the 'I' and the 'L', and a crowned fleur-de-lis bewteen two grains de remède above, the mark of Jean-Baptiste de Lens. Stamped on the centre of the underside of the lid. Charge mark, a crowned letter 'A', in use for the period 22 December 1732 to 4 October 1738. Stamped on the underside of the lid.
fields.public_access_description:
This lidded basin was almost certainly a bowl for sugar because its decoration matches a French teapot of the same date (also in the V&A). This suggests both were part of the same tea service. The sugar in this bowl was served in lumps, as there is no hole pierced in the lid to accommodate a spoon. Unlike seventeenth-century sugar boxes, this bowl has no lock, which reflects the falling price of sugar during the eighteenth century.
The delicately-cast festoons of flowers and leaves around the bowl and lid, and the fasces (a bound bundle of rods) ornament around the rim of the lid are common decorative motifs found in books of ornament designs in the first half of the eighteenth century. This is a refined and restrained example of a decorative style labelled 'rococo' by nineteenth-century art historians. The rococo style developed across Europe in the first half of the eighteenth century. It was a style characterised by the use of ornament designs drawn from the natural world, particularly flowers, leaves and marine motifs such as shells. These types of ornament are present around the bowl and lid of this example; the finial on the lid combines curving, cast cockle shells with a central cabbage-like motif.
Lidded sugar bowls, typically in the form of small pots like this one, were known as 'pots de sucre' in eighteenth-century France. They were usually placed on a low stand and the one for this bowl has been lost. There is a similarly-shaped sugar bowl of porcelain (mounted in silver-gilt) in the toilet service presented by Louis XV to his wife Marie Leczinska to celebrate the birth of their first son in 1729 (now in the Musée du Louvre).
Jean-Baptiste de Lens, the goldsmith whose mark appears on the lid and bowl, was the son of a  goldsmith and worked in Paris. He became a master goldsmith in 1712, when he took as his mark a crowned fleur-de-lys with his initials, 'J D L', a head and two pellets. He died in 1759.

fields.history_note: Nothing is known about the original or subsequent owners of this bowl. The South Kensington Museum purchased it for eleven pounds in Paris, but the vendor is not recorded. The original museum label dates the bowl 'about 1770'.
